headline: Snow Ice Cream
description: Snow ice cream is a fun winter-time treat the whole family can make with just 4 simple ingredients: freshly fallen snow, sugar, vanilla, and milk.

video.description: Mother Nature helps make this frozen old-timey treat.
video.name: Snow Ice Cream II

name: Snow Ice Cream

recipeInstructions.text: When it starts to snow, place a large, clean bowl outside to collect flakes.
When the bowl is full, mix in sugar and vanilla. Stir in just enough milk for desired consistency. Serve at once.

review.reviewBody: there's three feet of snow outside and this is the best part of it. absolutely delicious. I topped with berries and put it on a fresh brownie. Very refreshing.
I loved it
This recipe is really good, but it isn't the same as regular ice cream, so bear that in mind. Make sure to add more vanilla and sugar as needed.

I made the 1 C sugar, 2C milk, T vanilla. Very tasty. Suggestion tho, mix bought ingredients inside an hour ahead and refrigerate, this lets the sugar dissolve and then put your mix bowl in the snow to freeze it, then mix all ingredients. Much more Ice Cream look, touch and taste.

I've made snow cream for years...40 to be exact! The best way to mix up is mix the milk, sugar and vanilla to your preferred taste first. Then you add snow until you reach the desired consistency. This makes it much easier and you don't have to frustratingly have to keep adding one ingredient or another.
I loved it! me and my siblings made it and it was great!

I have made this since my little brother and I found a recipe without eggs (grosses me out). This can easily be scaled down and adjusted to your tastes (using chocolate, different sauces and add ins). I've always mixed the sugar, vanilla, and milk together and then the snow, which helps get rid of some of the grainy-ness that comes along with adding sugar after. Love to make this with my toddler--and she can help!
Awesome
It’s an okay recipe but you have to make sure you refrigerate the ice cream once you’re done adding the sugar, milk, etc or else it doesn’t turn out.
We didn't have sugar so we used powered sugar. The kids loved it.

Fun and very easy. My 3 yr old thought this was the "best ice cream" lol It really was pretty good, we each had a bowl. I reduced this recipe for 2 servings. Before I went out to gather clean snow, I whisked together the milk, sugar and vanilla until well mixed and a little frothy. With a plastic rice scooper, I scooped snow into a plastic 8 cup measure bowl with my 4 cups needed. Then used the scoop to mix the milk mixture into the snow. No lumps, just smooth snowy ice cream. Great use of a snow day and making memories as I remember my mom doing with me.

We love making snow ice cream in the winter, but I've always made it with condensed milk. I didn't have any on hand, so I came across this recipe. It was really good...we even cut it into 1/4 of the original recipe due to the amount of snow we had. Easy to do and was a hit with our kiddos. 
**One tip...be sure to pack the snow when you measure it. That way it will be a good consistency when you mix the other ingredients.
no yes we will
I made a smaller batch but this is a very good recipe. I will be making some more tomorrow!!
Very good, but if you want to flavor it, use kifier instead of milk!
I didn't use a full gallon and just kind of guessed on the measurements. It still was good though.
I grew up on this. We never used sugar. Just vanilla flavoring and sweetened condensed milk. It always comes out smooth and creamy.
A complete blast from the past! We made this growing up in OK. Not much snow here in coastal VA but when it comes down, this is a wonderful and easy treat to bring some of the outside fun indoors!
This is just like what my mother would make when it snowed. My husband agreed that it was what his mother made. Now my seven yr old has gotten to experience this unforgettable treat.
I made this and it ended in a disaster it looked DISCUSTING! but i think that you should just make it outside so that it doesn't melt
Delicious and super fun to make! Also very close to snow cones, you just need to add soda. Would make again.
Instead of sugar and milk , try condensed milk for smoother consistency and whatever extract for flavor. Add mochi and fruits (mango or strawberries) for added texture.
Its so good! I will definitely make this again!
I feel neglected that my mom didn't know this recipe. My 5 year old and I just made this and it's great and fun. We added chocolate chips and we are loving it.
I used chocolate milk and my kids and i were all very pleased with how easy and how good it turned out.
this is an amazing treat for the kids when its snowing!! i had no more vanilla extract so instead we used almond extract and it was just as good!!

Just made this with full fat coconut milk due to our daughters life threatening food allergies and it was delicious!!! I was nervous about making the subsitution but it worked so well! Def will be a new tradition in our house!!!!
This was my first time trying snow cream, and it was amazing!
Everyone loved it! Yum! Tastes just like what my mom used to make!
Just made this for a winter treat. We don't get much in Mississippi but a big snow this year it was on. My kids never had this opportunity.
Fun! I added some ginger powder and bananas to mine. My family all liked it.

Tasty, easy, and fun to make. I just made this with my kids for the first time. It's not as creamy as "real" ice cream, but so much faster to make. Everybody enjoyed it. My kids asked if we could make it again. Adding a little chocolate syrup would easily turn this into chocolate ice cream. A fun activity for a snow day.
Used 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 3/4 package of Swiss miss hot chocolate mix. It was delicious! Perfect after a snow storm.

Wow, I guess I thought my family was the only ones who really made this! Most people you know have never heard of it. When I went to put it in my recipe book, I googled it-dang! We would not have been able to wait for snow to fill up a gallon though! We would just go out, after a few inches of freshly fallen snow, and use the largest bowl we could find and heap it full of clean snow. We used evaporated milk (unless all we had was regular milk) and sometimes half evaporated milk and half regular. Sometimes we didn't have vanilla and it's good without it too. We never premixed ingredients-we loved the crunchiness of the granulated sugar-well, what kid doesn't?! Just sprinkle sugar across top (about 1/4 to 1/2 cup), add vanilla (we did 1/2 to 1 tsp per large bowl), and stir in milk to get the consistency you want! Never tried to change it up-it was perfect the way it is! Very sweet, very rich! Grab a bowl and a warm blanket and enjoy! You can try this in a small bowl first-just a dash of sugar, vanilla, and milk to see if you like it!
What an adorable and creative idea! Thank you!!!

My kids and I LOVED this recipe! The key is to watch how much milk you put in so it is not too wet. Mine appeared to be pretty dry still, but as you stir all the ingredients up and it begins to melt a bit, it works out perfectly. I also used Superfine sugar (you can find that in the baking aisle in a box) because some reviewers mentioned the texture of the sugar made it gritty. We will definitely be making this again the next time it snows. New family tradition for sure!!!

I made a lot less of it (hubby didn't want to try it and it was only me), so I added the ingredients little by little to about a cup of snow, watching the consistency and sweetness. Was surprisingly yummy!
I use cream in my snow cream and had to add more sugar and vanilla.

As I don't live on the East Coast, we didn't have access to the freshest snow this winter. We used some from out back of the house that was a little yellow, from what, we don't know. Anyway, it had a little extra zesty flavor to it that we haven't tasted before and didn't anticipate.

My family tried this for the first time today. I only used 1/2 cup of sugar with 1TBS of vanilla and the snow cream was still very sweet. I wish I had some coconut and rum, as suggested by Jonine, another rater, and condensed milk. The coconut and condensed milk would add more texture. The current recipe is too icey and melts really fast. It was fun trying this with my family, and we look forward to trying variations of this recipe.
We don't get snow often in the South but when we do I make this recipe. The kids love it and it's fun and easy for them to make.
Lots of snow today so we made snow cream. Yummy & lots of fun for the kids. We made as directed and again with chocolate milk. Thanks for a fun recipe!
Delicious! My family loved it!

Don't get the "first fall" of the snow, let it come down for a little bit before you collect it. I found that it had a lot of dirt and contaminates in it. I followed this recipe except I used a can of evaporated milk. Probably a little more vanilla than called for but it was awesome! My grandson added cocoa powder to his and after tasting it, it too was awesome. Because he had to stir to dissolve the cocoa though, his was more of the consistency of chocolate milk. Great recipe though.
Be very careful about how much sugar you add. One cup was a lot.
Very good! After I made it I put it in the freezer to make it like ice cream.:)
Good Thanks!
This is amazing and great with strawberry bits mixed in! :}
I loved it!!! although I added a little more vanilla to it but other wise, delicious!

This recipe is different because its not really based on taste, It's just suppose to just be a happy, fun thing to do with your friends and family. But it does taste good. :) A family favorite ingredient that I recommend is maple syrup, you could also try adding the peppermint for a minty sweet tang. Oh and a hint for people who said that it melted to fast, tried actually making and eating it outside, it makes it really fun, and doesn't melt!

Actually really yummy! My 2 year old loved it :)

I only used 1/3 cup of sugar and about a cup of milk, and it came out nice. Kind of like a vanilla sorbet,

I just made this with my daughter since we are having a snowy day today in Baltimore. This was really yummy and it taste just like ice cream. :-) This will now be our snow tradition. Thanks for this recipe.

This is the classic snow cream I grew up with! Tip: Mix your milk, vanilla, and sugar in a separate container very well before adding it to the snow. This helps cut down on the gritty sugar and incorporates the flavors better. You can also use chocolate or strawberry milk instead of the white milk. Oh and don't forget the sprinkles!!

I 100% LOVED this recipe! The consistency was almost like a shake. The kids loved it too. I made a special batch with Splenda instead of sugar and heavy cream instead of milk for me...low carb deliciousness! For our next batch we're going to add broken Oreos. Thanks so much for this recipe!
It took a little bit more milk to get it to look like ice cream, but it tasted delicious. Incredibly simple and so enjoyable. Great way to spend the snow-day with my family. Thanks

We make this, but to avoid the sugar being gritty we use confectioners sugar. Also the vanilla mixes in better if you mix it in with the first cup of milk, or better yet start with 1 cup of heavy cream to make it more decadent.
Perfect activity for snow days! Kids loved making it, we all loved eating it :) Thanks for sharing!

Amazing! We added 2 teaspoons of cocoa like another person suggested and it tastes so good. We just were in a chocolate eating mood :) Can't wait to make the original recipe. This was so easy and perfectly sweet.
Just like I remember from when I was a kid....I didn't really measure any of the ingredients. I just added some of each until it seemed right.
Haven't had snow ice cream since I was a kid. This is just how I remembered it! While the texture naturally isn't quite like real ice cream the flavor is!.
Always has been a child hood memorie for me, we didn't get alot of treats in our younger years.
what a great idea! My 2 year old daughter and I had so much fun making this!

Made this with my girls today. It was VERY easy and good. We added cinnamon and extra vanilla, and it was YUMMY! Also added a little bit more milk to make it creamy. This will become a tradition in our house when it snows.

I am so confused by the people that said the sugar wouldn't dissolve. You should've mixed the sugar, milk, and vanilla in a separate bowl before combining it with the snow and then there is no problem. Also for those that add egg just be careful since you are consuming a raw egg. This is the exact same recipe my Mother used when I was growing up and my brother and I loved making it. It's not suppose to be the best tasting ice cream in the world, it is just fun. So loosen up and enjoy some time with your kiddos and make snow ice cream!
Very good! I mix the milk, sugar and vanilla together and pour over the snow and then stir. The kids love this recipe!
the kids like it. we put in french vanilla coffee creamer and they liked it better.

I loved making this with the kids tonight! This isn't a gourmet ice cream, this is definitely about having some winter time fun with the kids! And they loved it too!
My only thought for next time is to warm the milk a bit to fully dissolve the sugar, and then re-chill the milk/sugar mixture. I think that may help the gritty texture from the cane sugar while eating the "ice cream".
i love the recipe

yum! I love snow cream. We most certainly had it in VA where I grew up, my mom made it all the time and we couldn't wait for snow so we could have it! Of course now I live in San Diego, so I guess snow cream is out, lol!

I've made snow ice cream with my girls for years. We only make it when there's a "quiet snow". This usually happens at night. The snow is very light and fluffy and clean. I beat 1 c. milk, 1/2 c. sugar, 1 tsp. vanilla & 1 egg in a large bowl, then add snow until it's all absorbed. Needs to be eaten immediately. The egg makes it taste more like homemade ice cream.

Love it! I made this with my dad every winter as a kid, now I'm making it with my kids along with some great memories. Thank you!! For those who had issues with undisolved sugar; mix it in the milk first then add to the snow.

Made it last night for the first time and I think this will become a fun tradition in my house! I used 1 cup heavy cream and 1 cup whole milk. Also, I mixed the milk, sugar, and vanilla together before adding the snow. It was great and more importantly fun!
ABSOLUTLY WONDERFUL!! This is better than store bought ice cream and very easy to make! My friend and I ate tons and never wanted to stop... love it!
great recipe, we did used heavy cream instead of milk and add the snow very slow after we did mix all the other ingredients.
It is yummy using coconut milk!

Yummy! Some complained about the consistency - the trick is to mix the 'kitchen ingredients' first, making sure the sugar is dissolved in the milk before pouring on the snow. 
Will make again!
Just made this with our first snow of the season. It was a fun project for all the kids, and we really enjoyed it!
I love snow ice cream and this was wonderful. I made it like the recipe said and it was a fun, yummy treat.
This was fun recipe to make with the kids during one of our snowstorms. I needed to cut the sugar in half but otherwise was ok for what it was.

Yum! Yum! Yum! Next time I will follow other reviewers advice and combine the sugar/milk (or cream) ahead of time to dissolve the sugar granules. Even with some extra "grit", this snow ice cream was a hit! Very sweet!

Fun, Fun for my kids...they just kept laughing as they ate their creamy snow=) My hubby kind of choked it down, as he is used to the solid, creamy store-bought ice cream, but overall this was perfect for our blizzardish day!
My family loves this recipe!

Simple and good. My 12-year-old has become an expert at making this. I tend to add extra vanilla because I like a more rich taste. Once we got a bit too much sugar in it, so we added cocoa and it was great! Thanks so much!

Fun recipe to make! I added too much milk, but it would have come out pretty good otherwise. Just for personal preference, I'd half the sugar. This is fun for the family, especially kids. My daughter enjoyed her bowl of snow!
It's good, but waayy too much vanilla in my opinion. One teaspoon is plenty! Otherwise it's perfect. Might I also suggest sprinkles?

This was fantastic--and my kids were able to help me every step of the way. The picture of the pink scoops with the berries made me think sorbet--so we blended a bag of frozen raspberries with the milk, sugar and vanilla, then mixed that entire mixture with the snow. It was delicious and totally fun to make!
Total hit with the kids and us! Half of this recipe is plenty. Will try it with chocolate tomorrow.
The secret to the best snow cream is to use only evaporated milk instead of whole milk. More calories? Of course. More flavor? Absolutely!
My kids loved this and it was so easy they made it by themselves! Try it with coconut extract too.... yum!

instead of suguar i used stevia for diabetic to making it diabetic friendly and used skim milk also added mushed up rasberry thawed it up in microwave and poured it over the icecream and mixed it up .. yummy

this was great! I set out making snow ice cream because....well it snowed. There are 2 snow ice cream recipes I made on this site, this one and the Snow Ice Cream I, I totally prefer this recipe over the other one hands down. This one was very much light, flavorful, and sweet. My sugar brokedown and melded with the recipe very nicely. My mom made snow ice cream all the time when I was a kid living in Newfoundland because it snowed all the time.. She alway used evaporated milk and it was awesome. But I won't be eating that way ever again because of this recipe. My family was soo impressed that I made 2 batches. And changed the 2nd batch by replacing the vanilla extract with Imitation Strawberry Extract and red food coloring to make Strawberry Snow Ice Cream...my family totally said this recipe ROCKS. I think using milk in this recipe made it light an airy. And I totally could replace the sugar with splenda and use lowfat milk. Awesome. it's a total keeper. Thank you very very much.
Gives a nice kick to mix in some baileys or other form of irish cream liquor
Great Childhood Memory!!

We made this "Snow Ice Cream" and ended up with lots of uses. It is great in coffee, with chocolate sauce on top and mixed around, in soft drinks, and with sprinkles or mandarin oranges on top. And it was lots of fun with the kids!
I LOVE snow ice cream. I add a little cocoa powder to me for some chocolate snow ice cream!

Very easy and yummy. Tastes just a vanilla snowball (/sno-cone). Try putting caramel syrup on top - it is perfect! Eat as much as you can the first night, it gets hard to scoop when it's not fresh. Seriously, go for the caramel sauce... gives it that richness that it's lacking.
Great yummy fun with the kids. We drizzled ours with chocolate and/or strawberry sauce and it was delicious. Hope it snows again soon!!!

TRY LEMON FLAVORING AND CANNED MILK :-)
I THOUGHT MY FAMILY WERE THE ONLY ONES TO MAKE THIS. BRINGS BACK THE VERY BEST
MEMORIES.
My mom made this for us kids when we were young, and now I love to share it with my nieces and nephews. This is much better suited for kids because it's more about the novelty than the taste.
